journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Sound radiation from in-plane vibration of thick annular discs with a narrow radial slot

article-meta.aff: School of Automotive Engineering, Kyungpook National University, Sangju, Kyungbook, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Hyeongill Lee, School of Automotive Engineering, Kyungpook National University, Sangju, Kyungbook, Republic of Korea. Email: hilee@knu.ac.kr

abstract.p: The vibro-acoustic characteristics of in-plane vibration in a thick annular disc containing a narrow radial slot are investigated with a hybrid approach combining numerical or experimental results with pre-developed analytical calculations. Structural eigenfunctions for in-plane vibrations of the disc are approximated as linear combinations of eigenfunctions for a uniform disc that has same material properties and geometric dimensions except for the slot. Acoustic radiations from the normal modes of the disc are calculated using a theoretical solution introduced in previous work for the uniform disc along with the results from the approximations of structural eigenfunctions. Vibration and sound radiation from the disc due to a harmonic force fixed to the disc outer surface are investigated using the mode expansion method. The effects of the circumferential distance between the radial excitation and slot on the vibro-acoustic responses are investigated using the same method. Finally, contributions of sound radiations from two split vibration modes to the overall sound radiation from the sample disc are also investigated. Based on these results, it can be concluded that the procedure suggested in this study has good accuracy in calculating the in-plane vibro-acoustic properties of a thick annular disc with a radial slot.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Many mechanical or electrical components have been modeled as annular or circular disc. The structural vibrations of circular or annular discs as well as the acoustic radiations from the vibration have been the topics of many studies conducted so far.1–14 Although most of the studies have focused on the out-of-plane flexural vibration of uniform discs and sound radiation from the vibrations, several researchers have studied the vibro-acoustics of circular or annular discs containing radial slot(s).4–9 For instance, Yu and Mote4 found that geometric asymmetries such as radial slots split some structural modes, but not all. Mote5 numerically studied the stability of the annular discs containing radial slots with finite element analyses. Shen and Mote6 investigated the flexural vibration of a circular disc having equally spaced radial imperfections and figured out that they split some of repeated eigenvalues. Also, the authors represented the modal vibrations of asymmetric disc as the syntheses of the structural modes of the uniform disc. Honda et al.7 utilized the mode expansion procedure to investigate the structural response of a circular disc containing an asymmetry to a harmonic excitation revolving around the disc. Rim and Mote8 used numerical and experimental stability analyses to investigate the unstable vibration of a circular saw containing radial slots. Lee9 investigated structural eigensolutions of an annular disc with four evenly spaced narrow radial slots and found that modal characteristics were substantially modified by the slots when the length of the slots exceeded a specific limit. Based on these results, the author claimed that the perturbation procedure introduced by Yu and Mote cannot accurately calculate eigenvalues of discs containing radial slots. Lee10 approximated structural vibration and sound radiation from a thin annular disc with four radial slots as linear combinations of vibrations and sound radiations for the corresponding uniform disc.

In many cases, practical components that can be modeled as circular or annular discs have thickness over the thin plate limit. In these cases, given proper excitation, in-plane vibration of such components generates considerable sound radiation that should be included to properly control the overall sound radiation from the components. Limited numbers of articles have covered in-plane vibration and/or sound radiation from the vibration of uniform circular or annular discs.11–14 Chen and Jhu11 examined the in-plane vibration and stability of a spinning annular disc and determined the effect of rotational speed on the natural frequencies. Irie et al.12 and Lee13 calculated natural frequencies of annular discs using the transfer matrix method. Lee13 introduced an analytical solution for sound radiation from the in-plane vibration of thick annular discs and verified the solution numerically and experimentally. Finally, Lee14 investigated the effects of disc geometry on the vibro-acoustic characteristics of thick annular discs.

In practical cases, many components which are modeled as thick annular discs have unavoidable or intentional asymmetries such as cracks, holes, or additional masses, etc. In these cases, the in-plane vibration of the components and sound radiation due to vibration are expected to be significantly affected by the asymmetries. However, vibro-acoustics for the in-plane vibration of an annular disc with asymmetries has not been investigated thus far.

The main focus of this study is to understand the in-plane vibro-acoustics of a thick annular disc including a narrow radial slot. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors for the in-plane vibration of the disc with free boundary condition are determined using a finite element analysis and are examined by the experimental modal analysis. In addition, variations in the modal strain energy distribution in the disc due to the slot and the effects of slot length on the structural eigensolutions are also investigated with finite element models. Normal modes of the disc are approximated as linear combinations of normal modes of the uniform disc with identical material and geometric dimensions. Acoustic radiations from the normal modes of the disc are also synthesized with modal sound radiations of the uniform disc. The modal sound radiations of the uniform disc have been calculated with an analytical solution introduced in the previous study.13 The results are validated using a boundary element calculation. Based on the results, the sound radiations from the disc due to a harmonic force applied at a radial surface are calculated using the mode expansion procedure. The proposed procedure is checked by comparing the results with numerical analyses using a boundary element model. Finally, contributions of acoustic radiations from two split structural modes to the overall sound pressure and total acoustic powers are also investigated.

The overall procedure for this study is illustrated with the flow chart given in Figure 1. As explained in the figure, the procedure comprises two main parts: one for the uniform disc (expressed in red) and the other for the sample disc (expressed in black). Figure 1.
Overall procedure for in-plane vibro-acoustics of a thick annular disc containing a radial slot.

If the vibro-acoustic characteristics of asymmetric discs are identified explicitly using the proposed procedure, various asymmetric factors (such as a crack or hole) in the mechanical components having annular shapes could be easily determined with a simple acoustic test. In addition, one can easily select the proper excitation method and response characteristics for this kind of test based on the vibro-acoustic characteristics clarified in this study.

Figure 2 illustrates the sample disc containing a narrow radial slot. Geometric dimensions and material properties of the disc are provided in Table 1. Figure 2.
A thick annular disc containing a narrow radial slot.
Table 1.
Disc geometric dimensions and material properties.
Dimension or property Uniform disc Sample disc
Outer radius (mm) a 139.0 ←
Inner radius (mm) b 82.5 ←
Disc thickness (mm) h 31.5 ←
Slot length (mm) – – 25.0
Slot width (mm) ɛ – 3.0
Mass density (kg/m3) ρd 7905.9 ←
Young’s modulus (GPa) E 213 ←
Poisson’s ratio ν 0.305 ←

Important assumptions for this study are as follows: (1) The sample disc is stationary with a free boundary condition. (2) Structural and acoustic characteristics of the disc are linear and time-invariant. (3) Fluid loading on the disc surfaces and acoustic scattering on the disc surfaces can be neglected. (4) Two radial surfaces of the sample disc generate entire far-field sound pressure and two normal surfaces do not generate any sound pressure. The major objectives of this study are as follows: (a) Determine the influences of a radial slot on in-plane vibrations and sound radiations from the vibrations of a thick annular disc. (b) Introduce a hybrid, semi-analytical procedure for the in-plane vibro-acoustics of thick annular discs having a radial slot. (c) Investigate the contributions of sound radiations from two split modes to the overall sound radiation and total acoustic power.

sec.title: Modal characteristics
sec.p: For a given geometric configuration and prescribed material properties, eigensolutions (natural frequencies and normal modes) for in-plane modes of a uniform annular disc can be obtained using the transfer matrix method introduced by Irie et al.12 and Lee.13 In this method, the displacements and forces at a given radial position are related to those at the inner radial edge by transfer matrix [T(ξ)] as follows (1){z(ξ)}=[T(ξ)]{z(β)} where, ξ = r/a and β = b/a represent normalized radial coordinates at an arbitrary radial location (r) and at the inner edge (r = b), respectively. Furthermore, {z(ξ)} is the state vector that expresses normalized displacements and forces at ξ and satisfies following relation. (2)ddξ{z(ξ)}=[U(ξ)]{z(ξ)}.
From equations (1) and (2), the transfer matrix at frequency ω was obtained from the relation given in equation (3). (3)[T(ξ)]=exp(∫βξ[U(ξ')]dξ')=[I]+11![∫βξ[U(ξ')]dξ']+12![∫βξ[U(ξ')]dξ']2 +…

Here, exp means exponential function that is defined as exp(x) = ex. By applying the boundary conditions at ξ = β and ξ = 1, the eigenvalue (λq) and normal mode (Φq) for the qth radial mode was determined from the transfer matrix [T(ξ)]. The accuracy of this approach has been confirmed by comparing the results with numerical and experimental results in the previous study.13 According to the results, all normal modes with nodal line(s) have repeated eigenvalues and corresponding modal displacements can be expressed as pure sinusoidal functions with respect to ϕ.12,13

The in-plane vibration characteristics of the thick annular discs containing asymmetries such as a slot or crack has not been clearly defined and any appropriate analytical solution has not been introduced so far. In this study, eigensolutions for the in-plane vibration of the sample disc which is explained in Figure 1 and Table 1 are investigated using numerical analyses and verified experimentally. First five in-plane modes are identified in the frequency range from 0 to 8.0 kHz with finite element model with 4400 solid brick elements and 6000 nodes.15

In the experimental modal analysis, the disc is excited with an impulse hammer (PCB GK291C) in the radial direction at the mid-plane of the outer radial edge measuring response (u··) at pre-determined position using an accelerometer (PCB 352C22). Using this test set up, the accelerance spectra u··/f(ω) of the sample disc are obtained from the radial excitation force f(t) applied at circumferential positions from ϕ = 0° to 352.5° with increment Δϕ = 7.5° and radial accelerations measured at ϕ = 15° at the mid-plane of the outer radial edge. The maximum frequency (fmax) and frequency resolution (Δf) are set to be 8.0 kHz and 1.0 Hz, respectively. From these 48 accelerance spectra, an averaged spectrum [u··/f(ω)]avg, shown in Figure 3, is obtained and natural frequencies and modal damping ratios of the sample disc are extracted from [u··/f(ω)]avg. In addition, normal modes of the disc are determined from the 48 measured accelerance spectra u··/f(ω) using a commercial signal processing unit. Figure 3.
Averaged accelerance spectrum [u··/f(ω)]avg of the sample disc.

The numerical and experimental results for the sample disc are summarized in Table 2, along with numerical data for the corresponding uniform disc. Here, q is the mode index that represents the number of nodal lines in the normal mode and l is a split index determined by the relative locations of the nodal lines with respect to the slot. As shown in the table, all of the in-plane eigenvalues decrease with the introduction of the slot and repeated eigenvalues for the modes with nodal line(s) are split into two distinct values. In addition, the normal mode for the lower eigenvalue has its maximum displacement at the slot (l = c) and the other mode has its minimum displacement at the slot (l = s). Further, eigenvalues for the l = c mode (λq,c) show big decreases from corresponding eigenvalues of the uniform disc (λq) but eigenvalues for the l = s mode (λq,s) are almost identical to λq. Also, modal damping ratios for the l = c modes are bigger than those of the corresponding l = s modes. In the l = c modes, large displacements concentrated on the root of the slot increase the modal damping ratios. Table 2.
Natural frequencies and vibration modes of the sample disc and corresponding uniform disc.

Furthermore, as one can figure out in the table, normal modes of the sample disc with l = c are globally distorted by the introduction of the slot. However, normal modes with l = s are not affected by the slot except for a very limited area, thus showing almost identical modal displacements to those of corresponding modes of the uniform disc. Modal displacements at the outer edge based on finite element analysis and experiment are compared each other and with those of the uniform disc in Figure 4. In the figure, one can clearly see the global shifts and local displacements concentrated on the vicinity of the slot in Ψ2,c and Ψ3,c. On the other hand, Ψ2,s and Ψ3,s show almost identical profiles to the corresponding Φ2 and Φ3. In addition, the numerical eigensolutions show good correlations with the results of experimental modal analysis in terms of shifts and localized modal displacements. Figure 4.
Normalized modal displacement at outer edge. (a) Ψ2,c, (b) Ψ3,c, (c) Ψ2,s, (d) Ψ3,s.

According to the previous study on the out-of-plane vibration of a thin annular disc with four equally spaced radial slots, the introduction of radial slots significantly alters the strain energy distribution in the disc. This alteration, in turn, causes changes in the eigensolutions such as natural frequencies and mode shapes.9 Modal strain energy density distributions in the sample disc are calculated numerically and compared with those of the uniform disc in Table 3. As one can see in the table, strain energy density distributions in the entire disc of the l = c modes are significantly affected by the slot but those for the l = s modes are hardly affected by the slot. For example, the strain energy density for the l = c mode is highly concentrated in the vicinity of the slot root and notably decreases in other parts of the disc. In addition, the total strain energy in the disc also notably decreases accordingly. However, in the l = s modes, the strain energy density distributions over the entire disc and the amounts of total strain energy for the modes are almost same as those of the uniform disc. Therefore, it can be concluded that the slot on the anti-nodal line alters the strain energy in the disc, resulting in significant changes in the corresponding eigensolutions as in the case of flexural vibrations of the thin annular disc with radial slots. Also, note that, even in the uniform disc, the total strain energies of the two modes with same q slightly different from each other. But the differences in the corresponding eigenvalues are negligible. Table 3.
Modal strain energy density distributions in the sample disc.

sec.title: Effects of slot length
sec.p: As one can infer from the Table 2 and Figure 4, the eigensolutions of in-plane normal modes are significantly affected by the slot. In addition, according to the previous study on the thin annular discs containing radial slots, variations in the eigenvalues and normal modes of the out-of-plane modes are proportional to the slot length.9 The effects of slot length on the eigensolutions are numerically investigated with six finite element models containing a radial slot of 0 to 25 mm lengths.

sec.title: Effects on eigenvalues
sec.p:
The variations in disc eigenvalues with respect to slot length are summarized in Figure 5 where λq,l is the eigenvalue of the disc with a slot, λq is the eigenvalue of the uniform disc, and α is the ratio of the slot relative to disc width defined as α = (a − r0)/(a − b). As shown in the figure, λq,c decrease significantly with increase in slot length while λq,s remain almost constant despite the increase in slot length. For instances, λ3,c with α = 0.45 decreases more than 6% from λ3 but λ3,s decreases less than 0.5% from λ3. Figure 5.
Variations in eigenvalues vs. slot length: (a) λ2,l, (b) λ3,l.

sec.title: Effects on modal displacements
sec.p:
The effects of the slot length on the normal modes are also studied with same finite element models, and the results are summarized in Figure 6. In the figure, changes in modal displacements in the radial direction at the outer radial surface for three slot lengths (α = 0.09, 0.27 and 0.45) are compared with each other. As one can see clearly in the figure, in the case of Ψq,c, global shift and localized displacement at the vicinity of the slot are significantly increase as the slot length increases. However, the modal displacements at the outer surface of Ψq,s are almost identical regardless of slot length. Figure 6.
Normalized modal displacement at outer edge. (a) Ψ2,c, (b) Ψ3,c, (c) Ψ2,s, (d) Ψ3,s.

sec.title: Synthesis of normal modes
sec.p:
According to the previous studies, the normal modes of thin annular discs containing radial slot(s) can be approximated with the normal modes of the corresponding uniform disc having an identical geometric configuration.6,10 By applying the same procedure to this problem and the normal modes of the sample disc (Ψq,l) are approximated as linear combinations of the normal modes of the corresponding uniform disc (Φj) as described in equation (4). Contributions from each mode of the uniform disc are determined from Fourier series expansions of the normal displacements at outer edge of the sample disc. The results of the expansions are summarized in Table 4. (4)Ψq,l(r,ϕ)≅∑jCjΦj Table 4.
Fourier series coefficients for the selected modes of the sample disc.
Mode shapes of uniform disc Fourier series coefficients (Cj)
Ψ2,c Ψ2,s Ψ3,c Ψ3,s Ψ0
Φ0 0.08 + 0.00i 0 0.45 + 0.00i 0 5.70 + 0.00i
Φ1 0.05 + 0.01i 0 0.16–0.01i 0.03 + 0.00i 0.43–0.13i
Φ2 1.00 + 0.00i 0.03–1.00i −0.03 + 0.01i 0.02 + 0.03i 0
Φ3 0.06–0.02i 0 1.10 + 0.00i 0.00–0.97i −1.27 + 0.04i
Φ4 0 0 0.13 + 0.01i 0.00 + 0.03i 0.37-0.01i

As shown in the table, Ψq,s can be expressed almost solely by Φq with the same q with very small contributions from other modes. The results are consistent with the results given in Figure 3 and Table 2 where Ψq,s are almost identical to Φq except for a very limited area around the slot. On the other hand, Ψq,c which are globally distorted by the slot should be expressed as linear combinations of various Φj. For example, Ψ2,s can be expressed only by Φ2 but Ψ2,c should be expressed as combination of all Φj.

The accuracy of this procedure is examined by comparing synthesized displacements with corresponding original displacements from numerical analysis or experimental modal analysis. Modal displacements at the outer surface synthesized using equation (4) based on the numerical or experimental Ψq,l are compared with corresponding original numerical/experimental data in Figures 7 and 8. As shown in the figures, synthesized and original data show good agreements for all expansions. Consequently, the linear combinations given in equation (4) approximate Ψq,l with reasonable accuracies thus verifying the proposed approximation procedure. Furthermore, acoustic radiations due to the modal vibrations of the sample disc are calculated based on the approximations. Figure 7.
Normalized modal displacements at the outer edge from numerical analyses and synthesis. (a) Ψ2,c, (b) Ψ3,c, (c) Ψ2,s, (d) Ψ3,s.
Figure 8.
Normalized modal displacements at the outer edge from experimental modal analyses and synthesis. (a) Ψ2,c, (b) Ψ3,c, (c) Ψ2,s, (d) Ψ3,s.

sec.title: Modal sound radiation for uniform disc
sec.p:
For a given geometric configuration and vibrating frequency, sound radiation from a uniform annular disc due to in-plane vibration can be calculated using an analytical solution introduced by the author in the previous study.13 In this method, two radial surfaces are treated as cylindrical radiators of finite length and the far-field sound pressure at a specific position rp can be calculated using the following equations. Refer to Figure 9 for the relevant configuration. (5a)Pq(R,θ,φ)=PqI(R,θ,φ)+PqO(R,θ,φ) (5b)PqO(R,θ,φ)=ρaeikqRπkqRsinθ|u··qO|hSinc(kqsinθh/2)(-i)q+1Hq1'(kqasinθ)cosqφ (5c)PqI(R,θ,φ)=ρaeikqRπkqRsinθ|u··qI|hSinc(kqsinθh/2)(-i)q+1Hq2'(kqbsinθ)cosqφ (5d)Sinc(x)=sin(x)x Figure 9.
Sound radiation due to the in-plane vibration of a thick annular disc in spherical coordinate.

Here, kq is the acoustic wave number of the qth in-plane mode, Hq is the qth order Hankel function, |u··qO| and |u··qI| are the amplitudes of surface acceleration on the outer and inner radial surfaces, respectively. The modal sound radiation for the qth radial mode Γq is defined from the calculated sound pressures on a large sphere Sv surrounding the disc, as shown in Figure 9. Details and validation of this procedure can be found in the previous study.13

sec.title: Modal sound radiation for disc with a slot
sec.p: As described in ‘Structural characteristics’ section, modal displacements for the l = c modes of the sample disc are globally distorted; therefore, sound radiation due to these modes cannot be directly calculated using equation (5). As an alternative, the modal sound radiations for these modes (Λq,c) are approximated as linear combinations of modal sound radiations of the uniform disc (Γj) as previously calculated. This procedure was proposed by the author and successfully applied to a thin annular disc, thereby obtaining accurate modal sound radiations for distorted modes.10

Consequently, sound radiation due to the in-plane modal vibrations of the sample disc can be calculated using the following equation, assuming that contributions from each modal sound radiation (Γj) to be Cj which are derived from structural eigenfunctions and are given in Table 4. (6)Λq,l(r,ϕ)≅∑jCjΓj

For instance, Λ3,c due to Ψ3,c which is linear combination of Φ0, Φ1, Φ2, Φ3 and Φ4 can be approximated with the following equation using equation (6) and Table 4. (7)Λ3,c(R,θ,φ)≅0.45Γ0+(0.16-0.01i)Γ10.45Γ0 +(-0.03+0.01i)Γ1+1.10Γ3+(0.13+0.01i)Γ4

On the other hand, sound radiation due to the l = s modes can be directly calculated using equation (5) since Ψq,s are almost identical to the corresponding Φq as shown in Table 5. Table 5.
Selected modal sound radiations of the sample disc.

Modal acoustic radiation properties such as Λq,l of the sample disc are calculated with uncoupled, direct, exterior and unbaffled boundary element analyses.16 In the computational study, 6146 acoustic field points and 6144 elements are defined on the sphere (Sv) surrounding the disc represented by the finite element model for structural dynamics. The center of this sphere coincides with the disc center. The excitations to this boundary element analysis are the normal velocity distributions on both radial surfaces u·(a,ϕ) and u·(b,ϕ) that are obtained from the normal mode analysis explained in ‘Structural characteristics’ section.

Selected Λq,l of the sample disc obtained using equations (5) and (6) are compared with the numerical calculations in Table 5 along with modal sound radiations for the uniform disc Γq. As shown in the table, analytically obtained modal sound radiations for the sample disc match the results of the numerical calculation quite well. In addition, modal sound radiations for l = s modes (Λq,s) are almost identical to the modal sound radiations for corresponding normal mode of the uniform disc (Γq). On the other hand, modal sound radiation for l = c modes (Λq,c) are quite different from Γq. This result is consistent with the structural data shown in Table 2, where Ψq,s are almost same as Φq regardless of the slot but Ψq,c are significantly affected by the slot resulting in substantially decreased eigenvalues and severely distorted normal modes.
Finally, the modal sound power Πq.l of the qth mode is calculated utilizing equation 8 based on the far-field approximation. (8)Πq,l=áIq,lSVñs=R22ρ0c0∫02π∫0πpq,l2sinθdθdϕ

Here, Iq,l are the sound intensity on Sv where the modal sound radiation is defined. Πq.l for selected normal modes are calculated from the modal sound radiation given in Table 5 using equation (8) and are explained in the Table 6 along with the numerical results. As shown in the table, the analytical calculations match reasonably well the numerical results. Also, all Πq.c are quite smaller than Πq of the corresponding uniform disc. This phenomenon is consistent with the displacement distribution in Ψq.c. In Ψq.c, modal displacement is concentrated in the vicinity of the slot and is decreased substantially in other part of the disc. Consequently, only small portion of the disc around the slot contributes to Πq.c and other part of the disc little contributes to Πq.c. Table 6.
Selected modal sound powers of the sample disc.
Mode indices Modal sound power (W) Remarks
Sample disc Uniform disc
q l Analytical Numerical Numerical
2 c 0.668 × 109 0.632 × 109 1.127 × 109
s 1.665 × 109 1.678 × 109
3 c 2.682 × 109 2.661 × 109 5.797 × 109
s 6.793 × 109 5.676 × 109

sec.title: Response of two split modes
sec.p: If the sample disc is excited by a unit harmonic force in the radial direction at a given circular frequency ω and location rf, several modes are excited simultaneously. Based on the mode expansion procedure, vibratory displacement δ on the surfaces of the sample disc can be expressed in terms of normal mode vectors of the disc using following equations (9){δ(ω)}={η(ω)}T{Ψ}{Ψ}={Ψ0,Ψ1,c,Ψ1,s,Ψ2,c,Ψ2,s,…,Ψm,s}{η(ω)}={η0(ω),η1,c(ω),η1,s(ω),η2,c(ω)2,s,…,η(ω)m,s}

In equation (9), Ψq,l is the modal displacement vector of the disc and ηq,l is the corresponding modal participation factor which can be calculated as follows (10)ηq(ω)=Ψq(rf)ωq2[1-ω2/ωq2+i2ςq(ω/ωq)] whenq=0ηq,l(ω)=Ψq,l(rf)ωq,l2[1-ω2/ωq,l2+i2ςq,l(ω/ωq,l)] whenq=1,2,…,m where ωq, ωq,l are the natural frequencies and ζq, ζq,l are the modal damping ratios, respectively.

Structural and acoustic responses of the sample disc for a radial excitation with circular frequency ω at the mid-plane of the outer radial surface are investigated with the aforementioned modal formulation. In the l = s modes where normal modes can be approximated accurately with Φq only, the radial displacement in the outer radial surface can be expressed as follows (11)uq,s(a,ϕ)=Uq(a)sinqϕ

However, if the normal modes are entirely distorted by the slot as in the case of Ψ2,c or Ψ3,c of the sample disc, the radial displacement in the outer radial edge must be expressed as following equation. (12)uq,c(a,ϕ)=∑CqUq(a)cosqϕ

Accordingly, the contributions of two split modes to the total vibratory displacement in the sample disc due to a harmonic force at the outer edge given rf = (a, ϕf) can be expressed as equation (13). Here, modal participation factors of the two split modes can be obtained as equation (14) based on the displacement in the outer radial surface that can be expressed as equation (11) or (12). (13)δq(ω)≅ηq,s(ω)Ψq,s+ηq,c(ω)Ψq,c (14)ηq,s(ω)=Uq(a)sinqϕfωq,s2[1-ω2/ωq,s2+i2ςq,s(ω/ωq,s)]ηq,c(ω)=∑CqUq(a)sinqϕfωq,c2[1-ω2/ωq,c2+i2ςq,c(ω/ωq,c)]

In the previous study, the author calculated the sound pressure from a uniform, thick annular disc due to a radial, harmonic force with circular frequency ω using modal sound radiations of the disc and structural modal participation factors.14 Adopting the same procedure for the sound radiation from the sample disc, the acoustic pressure on the sphere Sv in Figure 9, given the vibratory displacement of equation (9) is expressed as (15)P(ω)={η(ω)}T{Λ};{Λ}={Λ0,Λ1,c,Λ1,s,Λ2,c,Λ2,s,…,Λl,s} where, Λq,l is modal sound radiation defined previously. Therefore, the contributions of two split modes to total far-field sound radiation caused by a unit harmonic force at rf with circular frequency ω can be calculated with following equation. (16)P(ω)≅Λq,sUq(a)sinqϕfωq,s2-ω2+i2ςq,sωωq,s+Λq,c∑CqUq(a)cosqϕfωq,c2-ω2+i2ςq,cωωq,c

As one can infer from equations (13) and (16), the excitation location significantly affects the vibratory velocity of the disc and sound radiation generated by a radial harmonic force. For example, Ψq,s and Λq,s do not contribute to overall surface vibration and acoustic radiation for the sample disc when ϕf = 0 or ϕf = π.

The acoustic power spectra Π(ω) from the sample disc, given harmonic f(t) described above is also calculated from sound pressures on the sphere Sv using the following equation with the far-field assumption. (17)Π(ω)=12∫02π∫0πPH(ω)P(ω)ρ0c0R2sinθdθdϕ

sec.title: Experimental and numerical verifications
sec.p:
The analytical procedure proposed in this study is verified with experimental and numerical data for the sample disc. Since the relevant upper frequency limit in for the acoustic radiation study is 8 kHz, the first five modes are included in this validation study. In the experiment, a radial impulse force f(t) is applied by an impact hammer at ϕ = ϕf in the mid-plane of the outer radial surface. In the meanwhile, the radial accelerance spectra u··/f(ω), and the acoustic frequency response function p/f(ω) at a given receiver position on Sv are measured as shown in Figure 10. The sampling parameters for the test are set to be same as those given in the ‘Modal characteristics’ section. Figure 10.
Vibro-acoustic test setup for verification study.

In the numerical calculations, a forced vibration response of the sample disc for the unit harmonic force in radial direction at the excitation location given above is obtained using the finite element model described in the ‘Structural characteristics’ section. The acoustic radiation properties of the sample disc are also calculated with boundary element method. The acoustic field point mesh used for modal sound radiation in Chapter 2 is also used in this study. The excitation for this calculation is the normal velocity distribution on the two radial surfaces obtained from numerical forced vibration analysis described above.

The analytical accelerance spectra u··/f(ω) of the sample disc are calculated using equation (9) based on Ψq,s from equation (4) along with ζq,l from the experimental modal analysis. u··/f(ω) at a given receiver locations rs = (0.139, π/24) for a harmonic force applied at rf = (0.139, π/8) and rs = (0.139, π/4) are obtained utilizing three methods. The results are compared with each other in Figure 11 in which three results show relatively good agreements in the given frequency range, especially in the vicinities of the peaks. Therefore, it can be concluded that the procedure described in the ‘Response of two split modes’ section has a good accuracy in obtaining vibratory responses of the sample disc to a radial harmonic force. Also, it is clear that the contributions of Ψ2,c and Ψ2,s to the overall vibration of the sample disc for the excitation at rf = (0.139, π/8) are almost the same. In addition, the contributions of Ψ3,c and Ψ3,s to the overall vibration of the disc for the excitation at rf = (0.139, π/4) are also quantitatively similar. Note that the peak locations of the experimental data do not exactly coincide with those of numerical and analytical data. The discrepancies are caused by the differences in the eigenvalues of the disc obtained by three methods as explained in Table 2. Figure 11.
u··/f(ω) of the sample disc for rs = (0.139, π/24). (a) rf = (0.139, π/8); (b) rf = (0.139, π/4).

The acoustic frequency response functions p/f(ω) for the sample disc are also calculated using equation (15) based on Λq,l from equation (6) along with ζq,l from experimental modal analysis. The results for the receiver position rp = (1, π/2, π/8) for a unit harmonic force applied at rf = (0.139, π/8) or rf = (0.139, π/4) are compared with numerical and experimental results in Figure 12. As shown in the figure, the results from the three approaches match reasonably well in the given frequency range, thereby validating the proposed procedure. Figure 12.
p/f(ω) of the sample disc at rp = (1, π/2, π/8). (a) rf = (0.139, π/8); (b) rf = (0.139, π/4).

In addition, the acoustic power spectra Π/f(ω) for the sample disc are calculated using equation (17) based on the sound pressure distributions on Sv that have been obtained analytically. For example, given a circular frequency ω, the sound pressure at each field point on the entire Sv is calculated using equation (16). Then, acoustic power for circular frequency ω is calculated from this result using equation (17). The analytical Π/f(ω) for rf = (0.139, π/8) and rf = (0.139, π/4) obtained with this procedure compared with the numerical results in Figure 13. The results from the two approaches match well each other within the given frequency ranges. Figure 13.
Π/f(ω)of the sample disc. (a) rf = (0.139, π/8); (b) rf = (0.139, π/4).

sec.title: Effects of excitation location
sec.p:
The effects of excitation location on the accelerance spectra and acoustic frequency response functions are examined experimentally using the test setup introduced in the previous section. u··/f(ω) measured at a receiver position rs = (0.139, π/24) for an impulse hammer excitation at rf = (0.139, π/8) or rf = (0.139, π/4) are compared in Figure 14(a). In the figure, the effect of excitation location on ü f(ω) is clearly shown. In the rf = (0.139, π/8) case, contributions from Ψ2,c and Ψ2,s to the total vibration of the disc are almost same. But, in the rf = (0.139, π/4) case, the contribution from Ψ2,c is much smaller than that from Ψ2,s. In addition, the experimental p/f(ω) at rp = (1, 0, π/8) for the aforementioned excitations is also obtained using test set up given in Figure 9. The result is shown in Figure 14(b) where response characteristics similar to those of u··/f(ω) can be found. Therefore, it can be concluded that the overall sound radiation as well as the total surface vibration in the disc containing a radial slot could be controlled by the excitation location. Figure 14.
u··/f(ω) and p/f(ω) of the sample disc for two different excitation locations. (a) u··/f(ω) at rs = (0.139, π/24); (b) p/f(ω) at rp = (1, π/2, π/8). Key: ——, rf = (0.139, π/8); - - -, rf = (0.139, π/4).

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: The in-plane vibrations of a thick annular disc containing a narrow radial slot and acoustic radiations from the vibrations have been investigated. Structural eigensolutions (natural frequencies and normal modes) of the disc have been obtained numerically and experimentally. The results show that the global vibration modes of a disc containing a slot longer than a certain limit are distorted significantly and natural frequencies notably decrease when one of the anti-nodal lines coincides with the slot.

Distorted vibration modes of the disc were approximated as linear combinations of normal modes of the uniform disc with identical geometric configuration except for the slot. This procedure has been verified by comparing the approximations with original data. In addition, acoustic radiations due to the distorted structural modes were also approximated with the linear combinations of modal sound radiations of the uniform disc that were obtained using an analytical solution introduced in the previous study. The results were validated with finite and boundary element calculations for selected modes, thereby showing that the sound radiations from the in-plane modal vibrations of the thick annular discs containing a radial slot can be predicted with reasonable accuracy using the proposed procedure. In addition, the acoustic powers from a pair of split modes have been calculated based on modal sound radiations and validated with numerical calculation.

The modal expansion technique has been used to calculate vibratory and acoustic responses of the sample disc for a harmonic excitation in the radial direction at the mid-plane of the outer radial surface. Radial accelerance spectra at specific positions on the outer radial surface, the acoustic frequency response function at a given receiver position, and acoustic power spectra for the excitation have been calculated analytically and verified numerically.

Modal and multi-modal sound radiations due to in-plane vibration of thick annular discs having a narrow radial slot can be efficiently calculated by the procedure introduced in this article with reasonable accuracy. In addition, asymmetries such as slots, holes, or additional masses in the disc can be identified by examining the acoustic response characteristics of the disc. Finally, one can easily determine proper excitation method and response characteristics for this kind of tests based on the acoustic response characteristics.

Future study includes a simultaneous consideration of both out-of-plane and in-plane vibrations of the thick annular disc with a radial slot, and interactions between acoustic radiations from two kinds of vibration. Also, the coupling of two types of structural modes due to the radial slot could be investigated along with sound radiation from coupled modes etc.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was supported by Kyungpook National University Research Fund, 2012.
